So this lady‚Äôs at our house a few weeks before Christmas and we‚Äôre talking. The conversation turns to her partner needing some rare medication that‚Äôs easier to get in Mexico. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not sure about going to Mexico,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúOkay, I know it‚Äôs a Trump thing and all but those caravan people are there.‚Äù Whoa!

Apparently _those people_ aren‚Äôt really people. They‚Äôre like monsters getting ready to invade our country and rape our children. That‚Äôs the crap Donald‚Äôs been feeding people and millions are eating it up. Our country‚Äôs in a bit of a mess right now. I regret I was speechless at the time.

Saying more about that now just adds to the noise, so let‚Äôs move on. My mind swirled a bit when I first read this at Anne‚Äôs place and I‚Äôm still thinkin‚Äô about it:

‚ÄúWhy do you go away? So that you can come back. So that you can see the place you came from with new eyes and extra colors. And the people there see you differently, too. Coming back to where you started is not the same as never leaving.‚Äù - Terry Pratchett

From Colorado to Delaware to Florida to Illinois to Michigan. All the stops in one‚Äôs journey define who they are and going back to where one started is just a visit to another new, though familiar place.

Some stops in the journey border on unbearable but a new world is always just around the corner and when we‚Äôre lucky, it‚Äôs a better place.

‚ûù [time and place](https://simply.joejenett.com/time-and-place/)

So this lady‚Äôs at our house a few weeks before Christmas and we‚Äôre talking. The conversation turns to her partner needing some rare medication that‚Äôs easier to get in Mexico. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not sure about going to Mexico,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúOkay, I know it‚Äôs a Trump thing and all but those caravan people are there.‚Äù Whoa!

Apparently _those people_ aren‚Äôt really people. They‚Äôre like monsters getting ready to invade our country and rape our children. That‚Äôs the crap Donald‚Äôs been feeding people and millions are eating it up. Our country‚Äôs in a bit of a mess right now. I regret I was speechless at the time.

She told us there were liberals living next door as if we would think that was bad thing. ‚ÄúThey didn't like the sign in our yard.‚Äù Funny how easy it is to be so full of yourself that you think others would have to agree with you. You're on the right side of history after all. How could anyone not agree?
Some stops in the journey border on unbearable but a new world is always just around the corner and when we‚Äôre lucky, it‚Äôs a better place.
Be inquisitive. Know what you don't know.

doesn't want to be wrong but the fact is they made a bad choice and our country is going to shit
I don't think so. That 35% clings to Trump overlooking his daily absurdity and assaults on the
intelligence of the rest of the _American people_. It's understandable that the so-called base
‚ÄúWhen one part of America hurts, we all hurt.‚Äù
Okay, so does that mean that when 65% of Americans are hurting about the state of our government,  the other ~35% are also hurting?
Saying more about that now just adds to the noise, so let‚Äôs move on. My mind swirled a bit when I first read this at Anne‚Äôs place and I‚Äôm still thinkin‚Äô about it:
How ‚Äôbout the fact that I‚Äôm here to write this ‚Äì another chance to capture ideas ‚Äì my days are numbered. Your‚Äôs are too. There‚Äôs nothing more clich√© than *that‚Äôs life*.
I want to deal with what‚Äôs possible, not wallow is what‚Äôs already taken place and left its ugly mark.

I‚Äôm convinced the thought that fills my mind most of the time is just a complex of [reactions](reactions.md) to the strange world I‚Äôm living in. Creative [urges](urges-1.md) struggle to redirect my mind to what I don‚Äôt see, to what might be.
I‚Äôm tickled you‚Äôre here reading this. I may not know you nor get feedback but that‚Äôs okay. I still have a chance to touch you in some way with what I share ‚Äì what could be better than that!
There‚Äôs a number of other pleasant memories since then through the next 5 years or so but many moments in my youth thereafter were destined to become repressed memories as an adult.
touch my mind and watch it bleed
I think ‚Äúthe future of awesome‚Äù really means ‚Äúnot quite awesome yet.‚Äù üòé

‚ÄúWhy do you go away? So that you can come back. So that you can see the place you came from with new eyes and extra colors. And the people there see you differently, too. Coming back to where you started is not the same as never leaving.‚Äù - Terry Pratchett
The thing about repressed memories is that they never really go away.

There‚Äôs many words that could use a little tweaking to make their meaning a little more clear or at least, a little more descriptive in terms of the reality they describe. Adding or deleting a single character (as in ‚Äòhealthscare‚Äô) or changing a syllable slightly (as in ‚Äòpolitricks‚Äô) brings us closer to a word‚Äôs true meaning.

I can remember walking around the old neighborhood wondering what water temperature would be best for washing my hair. I also thought about whether or not I would ever have it cut again. It had grown quite long while I was in school and coming back to the neighborhood after almost four years was awkward for me to say the least. I needed to find a job quick. Living in that old house again on Royal Palm Avenue with my mother wasn't an option. I wouldn't have been able to handle that for very long and as it turned out, I didn't have to. Nor did I cut my hair.
Then again, one's own experience or perspective might come into play here - I know - I‚Äôm kinda silly...
An odd example as if it was written by an angry misogynistic guy or something. I‚Äôm just saying...
So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.

From Colorado to Delaware to Florida to Illinois to Michigan. All the stops in one‚Äôs journey define who they are and going back to where one started is just a visit to another new, though familiar place.
- There are things I want to understand but never will and there are things I understand no one else would ever want to.
the un-followed and the birth of creativity

The web has changed but there remain remnants of what it once was in terms of personal sites. I track some of those remnants, curating such sites (which are still active, or when I‚Äôm lucky, new), hoping to somehow keep my original vision of the web intact. It‚Äôs a tough road to drive on but I‚Äôve got a decent set of wheels with a few bells and whistles and more important, I enjoy the driving.
because of it being that way.
Coming to, coasting through spaces between trees, he recovers unscathed, living to tell the story 50 years later.
The mobile version works best in landscape mode.
When we discovered Sliding Rock, we had not bathed for days camping up in the mountains. The cold plunge pool below was totally rejuvenating.
I've been spending time gathering ideas in the [garden](https://ideas.joejenett.com) ‚Äì check it out and yeah, thanks for stopping by.
I spent some time today improvising lyrics to a slow 4-chord progression. What fun!
